source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: three quarters of the lifetime is consumed by crack initiation for times-to-failure in the range of 30 to 1200 min

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: fraction of life spent in initiation increases as temperature decreases

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: Peehs et al [27] found that approximately half of a 180-min split-ring test at 400°C is consumed by crack formation

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: A tube pressurization test by Peehs et al [28] at 400° and 225 MPa showed a strong acoustic emission signal within the first 20 min of a 600-min test

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: Microcracks form preferentially where basal poles are 50 to 75 deg from the radial direction

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: specimens with the more tangential texture develop cracks more readily than similarly stressed specimens with a more radial texture

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: lifetime at 320°C in the tests from this study is controlled by crack initiation

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: Initiation often occurs in large (10 to 30 μm) pits

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: a larger density of cracks is associated with larger strains; this trend is most evident in the 390°C specimens

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: Several percent strain is required to cause cracking in recrystallized material

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: Threshold stress values decrease as the irradiation effect on mechanical properties approaches saturation

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: SCC susceptibility is substantially increased compared with unirradiated material

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: Macroscopic plastic strain at failure is substantially reduced

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5
evidence_span: Extensive incipient cracking is observed in tube pressurization tests at 325 and 360°C

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk5

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: a higher fraction of basal poles oriented in the crack opening direction should correspond to easier crack propagation. Such a texture has both a lower $K _ { \mathrm { I s c c } }$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: a higher fraction of basal poles oriented in the crack opening direction should correspond to easier crack propagation. Such a texture has ... a higher crack velocity at any $\pmb { K }$ above threshold

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: The Region II velocity, where crack velocity is less dependent on $\pmb { K }$ than just above $K _ { \mathrm { I s c c } }$ , is higher for the texture more favorably oriented for propagation (NL and NT orientations) compared with the less-favorable texture (TL orientation)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: The cold-rolling of the plate imparts a "pancake" shape to the grains which gives a different microstructure ahead of the NL and NT cracks compared with the TL cracks

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: The texture in the crack opening direction is the same for both the NL orientation and the NT orientation. $K _ { \mathrm { I s c c } }$ is the same for both orientations while crack velocity is higher for the NL orientation

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: crack velocity is higher for the NL orientation

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: Metallography of tube cross sections and SEM observations of the tube inside diameter show sharp cracks as small as one or two grains

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: Videm and Lunde [26] found that a 50-μm crack decreases the threshold stress compared with unflawed specimens

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: three regions of behavior are observed: (1) smooth-bar threshold behavior where threshold stress does not depend on flaw size, (2) short crack regime where threshold stress decreases but where fracture mechanics is not applicable, and (3) a long crack regime where fracture mechanics is valid and threshold stress versus log $\pmb { a } _ { 0 }$ exhibits the characteristic-1/2 slope

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: essentially all the lifetime at $3 2 0 \textdegree$ is consumed by crack propagation at the threshold stress

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: lifetime is intiation-controlled for the smoothbar threshold

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk6
evidence_span: differences in chemistry between the fracture mechanics experiments (flowing system with iodine replenishment) and the tube pressurization tests (static system with fixed quantity of iodine)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk7
evidence_span: Effect of Direction of Approach to Temperature on the Delayed Hydrogen Cracking Behavior of Cold-Worked Zr-2.5Nb

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk8
evidence_span: The delayed hydrogen cracking behavior of cold-worked Zr-2.5Nb at temperatures above about 23,45 depends upon the direction of approach to test temperature.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk8
evidence_span: Cooling to the test temperatures results in an increase in crack growth rate, da/dr, with increase in temperature, given by the following Arrhenius relationship da/dt = 6.86 × 10^-1 exp(-71500/RT)

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk8
evidence_span: Heating from room temperature to the test temperature results in the same increase in da/dr with temperature, but only up to a certain temperature, Tpar.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk8
evidence_span: The temperature, TbAr, increases with the amount of hydride precipitated during cooling to room temperature, prior to heating, and with cooling rate.

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_044_chunk8
evidence_span: Pressure tubes fabicated from cold-worked Zr-2.5Nb are used extensively in CANDU (CANada Deuterium Uranium) nuclear reactors.
